newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Mandate of U.N. observers in Tajikistan renewed.
newsitem.headline: Mandate of U.N. observers in Tajikistan renewed.

text.p: The Security Council on Friday renewed until March 15, 1997, the mandate of a 96-member U.N. Mission of Observers in Tajikistan (UNMOT), where a four-year civil war between the secular government and Islamist guerrillas has claimed tens of thousands of lives.

The renewal was conditioned on the remaining in force of a 1994 Tehran agreement on the cessation of hostilities and on the parties demonstrating their commitment to a ceasefire, national reconciliation and the promotion of democracy.

The council's unanimous resolution condemned the "ongoing flagrant violations of the ceasefire by the parties," particularly a recent opposition offensive in the Garm region, east of Dushanbe, the capital, and demanded an immediate cessation of all hostilities and acts of violence.

It also condemned "terrorist acts and other acts of violence" which claimed the lives of civilians, members of a peacekeeping force fielded by the Commonwealth of Independent States, and Russian border forces.
The resolution called on the parties to cooperate with the U.N. special representative for Tajikistan, Gerd Merrem, in resuming inter-Tajik talks to achieve a comprehensive political settlement.
It welcomed a meeting December 10-11 between Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov and opposition leader Sayid Abdullo Nuri and encouraged them to continue the dialogue.
